text:
The doc for the userId field on completion request says

```  // Required unless authentication is used with a user token.
  // In that case, the token's user-id will be used for the request's user_id.```
Can you check you’re calling it with a token for that user as well? (if you have auth enabled)

text:
We are flabbergasted by the problem as your scenario should work. We need to get more creative in order to find out the root of the problem.
Could you check if you can query pings similar to what i have done above?
• you need to know the built-in participant party, for instance like this `curl <http://localhost:4444/v2/parties> | jq`  
• use that party to query for the completions
```curl --silent -d '{"beginExclusive":0,"parties":["participant1::122095e6f69fd62d787c1f05065496d87443be9909864de8b39273395701554216fc"],"userId":"PingService"}' POST <http://localhost:4444/v2/commands/completions> | jq```

text:
So it seems there is a path forward to bind a `submissionId` with an `updateId`, however this would complexify quite a lot our logic as we would have to index the completion stream of each validator we are managing.

Do you have a timeline to make the endpoint `/v2/interactive-submission/execute`  synchronous?

submissionId
with an
updateId

, however this would complexify quite a lot our logic as we would have to index the completion stream of each validator we are managing.

/v2/interactive-submission/execute
synchronous?

text: When starting an SV scratchnet, how is the latest Splice version determined? I'm trying to understand why a `0.4.5`-based scratchnet is using `splice-amulet-0.1.9` rather than `splice-amulet-0.1.11`. Thanks!

elements.text: When starting an SV scratchnet, how is the latest Splice version determined? I'm trying to understand why a
-based scratchnet is using
splice-amulet-0.1.9
rather than
splice-amulet-0.1.11
. Thanks!

text: In theory it should use the latest version available unless you overwrite `initialPackageConfig`

elements.text: In theory it should use the latest version available unless you overwrite
initialPackageConfig

text: Note that versions don't autoupgrade though. If you boostrapped on an older version and then upgraded to 0.4.5 this is expected

elements.text: Note that versions don't autoupgrade though. If you boostrapped on an older version and then upgraded to 0.4.5 this is expected

text:
It’s currently planned for Canton 3.4 which as far as I know is currently planned for fall.
I also want to emphasize that relying on the completion event (or using the future synchronous version) comes with the caveat that it requires trusting that the completion is correct and therefore that the executing node is honest, when submitting transactions that are not self conflicting (for instance creating a contract or exercising a non-consuming choice). Otherwise a dishonest node could incorrectly respond with a completion saying that the transaction failed and trick the application into re-submitting.

elements.text:
It’s currently planned for Canton 3.4 which as far as I know is currently planned for fall.
I also want to emphasize that relying on the completion event (or using the future synchronous version) comes with the caveat that it requires trusting that the completion is correct and therefore that the executing node is honest, when submitting transactions that are not self conflicting (for instance creating a contract or exercising a non-consuming choice). Otherwise a dishonest node could incorrectly respond with a completion saying that the transaction failed and trick the application into re-submitting.

node

text:
> By `node` you mean the `participant node`  ?
Yes
> As we are running it ourself, can it be trusted?
If you run it yourself I’d expect that you can reasonably trust your own nodes yes (but that’s ultimately dependant on the security around your node deployment etc…). This becomes more relevant if you were to call execute on nodes you don’t operate for whatever reason
